posts.content:
Join us as Miranda Rodigas, Head of Scheme Partnerships, Worldline discusses the future of Frictionless Payments with, VP, Marcomms from

In this snippet, from The Economy of Trust series, youâ€™ll be able to discover some of the key elements that define a seamless payment experience and how thatâ€™s transforming the financial landscape of today.

Want to know more? Stay tuned for insights that could reshape your understanding of payments and trust in the digital age!

Watch the full episode here:

comments.commentText: Explore the future of frictionless payments with insights from Miranda Rodigas of Worldline and Victoria P. of JCB International. Discover how seamless payment experiences are revolutionizing the financial landscape. Watch the full episode here:

The "Economy of Trust" is reshaping global financial landscapes with seamless, secure, and efficient payment experiences. Blockchain, encryption, and multi-factor authentication are building trust in digital transactions, while global frameworks like PSD2 ensure transparency and fairness. Fast, convenient, and secure payments are driving the adoption of mobile wallets and contactless payments. Startups are enhancing financial inclusion with alternative payment methods, and companies like Wise are reducing fees and improving speed in international transfers. AI and machine learning are enhancing fraud detection and personalization, boosting trust in payments. The future of finance is digital, secure, and driven by trust.

posts.name:
Anthony Wentzel
Anthony Wentzel
posts.content:
Ditch a development team that doesn't challenge your ideas!

The ones who just execute, invoice, and move on.

Why?

Because they are the types that'd give you just what your order is and not necessarily what you need.

They are the types who won't care to learn more about your business than the bare minimum.

No.

Work only with a team that shows genuine interest in your business and its needs,

...beyond the app or digital product you're trying to build.

Do that, and the development of your product will not only be faster,

You'll have more happy customers and generate more revenue.

posts.content:
ğ—” ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—´ğ—²ğ˜ğ—®ğ—¯ğ—¹ğ—² ğ˜ƒğ—²ğ—»ğ—±ğ—¼ğ—¿ ğ—¹ğ—¼ğ˜€ğ˜ â‚¹ğŸ°.ğŸ± ğ—°ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—² ğ—¶ğ—» ğ—® â‚¹ğŸ­ğŸ¬ğŸ¬ğŸ¬ ğ—–ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—² ğ—§ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ—¿ğ—²ğ˜€ ğ—½ğ—¼ğ—»ğ˜‡ğ—¶ ğ˜€ğ—°ğ—µğ—²ğ—ºğ—² ğ—³ğ—¿ğ—®ğ˜‚ğ—±

Torres Jewellery, opened six stores across Mumbai in February 2024.

But it wasn't actually a real jewellery business at all. Torres sold fake jewellery and told people they would get amazing returns on their money - starting at 6% and going up to 13%.

The company mainly floated four schemes:
â€¢ Invest in gold for a weekly interest of 2%,
â€¢ Silver for interest of 3%,
â€¢ Moissanite stones in silver for 4% interest
â€¢ Investments only in Moissanite stones for an interest of 5-6%.

The scheme operators gradually increased the interest rate towards the end of the year to extract more money from the investors.

To make people believe they were legitimate, they even gave away fancy prizes like cars and expensive phones.

They asked people to invest in cash to get a weekly interest of 11.5% if invested in cash.

Due to the bonus interest in cash investments, many people invested in cash and now worry if police will be able to recover their cash investment in the fraud amount.

Initially people invested money and after getting timely returns they invested more and also encouraged their family members, relatives, friends etc.

And if any investors bring new investors, then the person would get a 20% interest on investment for referral.

There are investors who were operating like agents, as they brought dozens of investors to the company, and were earning the referral bonus/interest.

Eventually they too lost all their money

To make investors trust them, the senior executives while conducting seminars would say that they get gold at a cheaper rate and they make a 300% profit on it. From this 300% profit they are able to give these unbelievable returns to the investors. This convinced investors and they made huge investments.

Just before Christmas 2024, when they had collected money from about 125,000 people, Torres suddenly shut down all their stores and vanished.

The scammers also put up pictures and names of three random people on their website, trying to blame them for everything.

The scam came into light when a vegetable vendor Khar Pradipkumar Vaishya, 31 who along with his relatives lost Rs 4.5 crore to the fraud and complaint to the police.

The company also staged a fake robbery to buy more time to wind up everything and run away.

Police have arrested company's GM Taniya Xasatova alias Tazagul Karaxanovna Xasatova, director Sarvesh Ashok Surve, and store in-charge Valentina Ganesh Kumar.

Ankit Uttam who to blame greedy people or the government!

Dr. Puneet Mohan If someone wants high returns and is ready to risk his life savings then government cannot stop you. You are free to use or invest your money.

So, it is up to the individual to do his due diligence.

Ankit Uttam most of my friends circle, compromises of banayas, that to Agrawals, although the confusion still persists whether single 'g' ya double 'gg', , but most being sarrafs, the formula is clear, 1 re. me lete hai aur 1.5 ya 2 rs dete hai (borrowing rate 12% pa and lending 18-24% pa). Man they have evolved and grown to national level lending players. Unrealistic returns are an open grave . Jao aur soo jayo

HR Swati Sharma
posts.content:
If you're aiming for a clear understanding of CTC breakdowns, here's a guide to help during HR negotiations (assuming no variables are included):

- 10 LPA CTC = â‚¹68,000 per month
- 20 LPA CTC = â‚¹1,20,000 per month
- 30 LPA CTC = â‚¹1,75,000 per month
- 40 LPA CTC = â‚¹2,28,000 per month
- 50 LPA CTC = â‚¹2,82,000 per month

These figures are based on a 12% Provident Fund (PF) deduction and a basic salary component making up 50% of the total.

To push for a higher package, focus on negotiating stock options first, as the annual bonus will usually remain fixed. Keep these numbers in mind for your next HR discussion!

Adhip Prabhu
Adhip Prabhu
posts.content:
Swiggy has always been synonymous with convenience and innovation in food delivery. But with recent launches like Pyng: a platform for nutritionists and yoga professionals and SNACC: promising 15-minute food delivery, the brand is clearly evolving beyond just food delivery. While these initiatives open new doors, they also come with their share of challenges.

Swiggyâ€™s foray into health and quick commerce is an exciting evolution, showcasing its ambition to be more than just a food delivery app. While the potential is huge, success will depend on execution, sustainability, and how well Swiggy balances innovation with its core brand values.

Whether these new ventures are the future of Swiggy or a passing experiment, one thing is certain: Swiggy is unafraid to push boundaries.

What are your thoughts on these new moves? â€ï¸
